reviewText:
This game genuinely makes me happy.

The devs succeeded in creating a really atmospheric puzzle game. The music really mellows you out, and the artwork is fitting extremely well done; simple but elegant. The puzzles come in all shapes and sizes with a few minigames for variety's sake. They arent easy enough to make the game boring, nor are they impossible because of the game's voluntary hint system (which I think is clever). Even the one or two hard puzzles that you can't use hints on (I'm looking at you world map) are beatable if you rack your brain a bit and give you a pleasant sense of accomplishment. Its a game that one would enjoy playing between games, something to relax and fall in to after a disasterous game of league, doto, or cs.

My only complaint is that this game is too short and that I'm going to miss it when I finish it :c

Trusting only the reviews, I bought this game on a whim without much knowledge of what the game was. The art style reminds me of original Pixar sketches and are aesthetically flushed in simple pastels and coloured in complementary contrast tints of green, blue, orange, brown and grey.

Unlike the storyline offered in the description, it didn't seem as if I was saving a planet as everything seemed hunky-dory despite the meteor hit. Instead, as I was still fixing odd broken gadgets here and there, it felt as if I were the new mechanic on Tiny Planet and through my work, the tales of its inhabitants were shown to me in a fabular form. These are tales of life and happy souls which will lighten your spirits from all megrims and entertain with a puzzle variety ranging easy to medium which are all jolly good fun. It has been the most enjoyable hidden object game I've played on Steam as through the course of most of this game you will be searching for a variety of items to fix things and open up new paths and stories.

Other than hidden object puzzles and jigsaws, the puzzles consist of sequential move puzzles using 2D sliding puzzles as well as tiling puzzles, construction puzzles, 8-bit games, memory games and code breaking puzzles. Keeping in mind that is entertaining and soothing for adults, it hasn't any word games and lacks any true challenge that would be too different to progress through for children. It has the medium difficulty crucial for enjoyment from wider audiences so you'll definitely spend time figuring things out but none will take more than a few minutes for mature or experienced puzzlers.

Tiny story indeed. A soccer ball hits the world and turns it into a jigsaw puzzle. There's your story. The ending is even worse.

Of course it has somewhat of an excuse: it's a very casual hidden object game; lots of tiny things to click on, pretty art set at a relatively tiny (but acceptable) box resolution and a tiny amount of options/configuration.

You're thrown into a scene of half a dozen screens or so and left to click on things for goals to pop up, usually to find X amount of other things to progress or solve a puzzle. There are several areas and maybe 25-30 explorable screens total, not counting puzzle screens. You also find jigsaw pieces throughout and piece some of your world back together on the title screen after each major area.

There are sliding, jigsaw and pipe puzzles and other minor brainteasers. The best thing I can say about the game is it looks very nice and is charming, the worst that it leaves you feeling you accomplished very little, if anything at all.

reviewText:
Charming game. Cute art, nice relaxing music.

Your mission is to put the world back together by finding all the puzzle pieces from each level to puzzle together the next one until you've finished building the world. A casual playthrough takes a bit more than 2 hours.

Some hidden objects can be quite hard to find/see. Imo the hint button recharges too slowly. You need to click 20ish flies on the screen for them to fill up to give you a hint charge. I don't mind games being hard, but this is just inconsistent with the relaxing, casual feel I get from the rest of the game.

The minigames are mostly fairly easy. The computer game simulating games are really frustrating though. Extremely slow, I ended up killing myself more than once by crashing into walls because the little ship/plane was so slow.

The jigsaw puzzle at the end of each level a have too many pieces. I quite like jigsaw puzzles, but it just takes too long and I lose interest and get bored of it.

You have to discover the puzzles to be able to pick up the items needed for them, like Morphopolis, which isn't too much of a problem as they're mostly obvious and easy to find.

Overall worth buying if you're into point&click/hidden object games, but be aware of a few frustrating elements.

reviewText:
For me, hidden object games are taking one of the worst elements of traditional point-and-click adventure games, pixel hunting, and making that a genre. I don't understand the appeal and find it frustrating and stupid in general.
I enjoyed some of the other puzzles in this game, but the couple that are roadblocks to your progress are at odds with how easy the game is in general.
The jigsaw section that you play between levels is garbage, as the pieces change colour after being placed, so you can't even match some of them properly.
The graphics are quite nice and remind of Samorost a bit, but could use some more click interactions with background objects; like clicking a bell would make it swing and ding.

If you enjoy pixel hunting games for some reason you may have a better time with this than I did, but I wouldn't recommend it.
Try Machinarium, Botanicula, or Safecracker: The Ultimate Puzzle Adventure instead, which I actually enjoyed.

An incredible. I bought it for just $10 pesos (like $0.99 dollars or even less).

I expected it to be very simple and boring, basically a broken game coded in one day or so. I could not be more wrong.

I truly recommend this game. If you can afford the game, have time to spend, like to think about problems and have a big screen (to compensate the more or less low resolution), then, you need to buy it.

reviewText:
The bulk of Tiny Bang Story is a hidden objects game. You start out searching for jigsaw puzzle pieces, and as you interact with things you are informed of other things you need to find in order to access puzzles. When you complete enough puzzles on the few screens for each level, you are taken to the world screen to place the jigsaw pieces. There are five levels, and 25 puzzles.

The art direction for this game is fantastic, and the music, while repetitive, is rather soothing. This is definitely a game to play for relaxation and puzzle solving; there is no hardcore setting in Tiny Bang Story. There's also no story once you start playing. I streamed the game expecting something engaging, and did not get that.

GameplayThe hidden objects portion of the game is tedious, but there are little blue flies you can click on to fill up your hint ball. Once the hint ball is full, you can click on it to send a red hint fly around the screen to orbit an item you haven't yet clicked on. If there are no such items on that screen, nothing happens, and you know you haven't missed anything on that screen.

Most of the actual puzzles are fairly rudimentary, and are things you've seen before. There are a couple that are very good though, most notably the water pipe puzzle in the last level. It is absolutely possible to solve it from scratch, and it is easily the most challenging puzzle in the game.

The worst puzzle is the astrolabe puzzle in level 3, which isn't a puzzle at all: you just rotate the thing until the lines all line up. Level 2 has what's basically a Simon machine, which is also not really a puzzle, and there are a handful of minigames scattered throughout as well.

One thing worth noting is that it doesn't actually matter whether you collect all the jigsaw puzzle pieces, as you will always have the correct amount upon completing a level. Also, three spoilers that will make your game a lot easier: the wheel for the train is in the example diagram, both clear flasks in level 2 are downstairs, and you must rotate the astrolabe counter-clockwise in order to finish it quickly.

I finished it in 4 hours, and a fair portion of that was on level 1 while I was still getting used to the game mechanics. There's also no replay value, especially considering what the ending is. I give it a 6.5/10, and I'd say it's worth playing if you can get it on sale.

Short version: 81%
An enchantingly beautiful hidden object type game which is also a perfect tool for teaching children. The short length may not keep you occupied for more then a few hours, but that will be one of the most wonderful few hours you spend in front of your monitor.

Long version:
The Tiny Bang Story is a short and sweet hidden object puzzle game. Since these kind of games are a dime a dozen, it‚Äôs hard to stand out among them, and luckily Tiny Bang Story knew exactly how to do it: with its style. All scenes feature gorgeous hand-drawn graphics which also help hiding the various collectible objects, since they blend in even more than in some other hidden object games.

Apart from the visual style the game is aiming for an interesting artistic goal: not a single word is spoken, nor there is any kind of writing, anywhere, apart from the mandatory main menu. Everything is told by visuals, which is always a great challenge for any artist, and the game achieves this flawlessly.
This also makes the game perfectly suitable for little children, which is also supplemented by the modern (somewhat steampunk-like) fairy tale theme and the soothing music. It‚Äôs not a child‚Äôs game per se as it‚Äôs more than enjoyable for adults too, but it may also serve as a really good tool to help the cognitive development of the little ones.

The negatives? The game‚Äôs puzzles are set, so replay value is fairly low. Also, the game is quite short, shorter than some Big Fish Games hidden puzzles, clocking around 2-4 hours. And the downside of the hand-drawn graphics is that the game has only one resolution (naturally it supports full screen and windowed modes).

reviewText:
Tiny Bang Story is primarily a hidden object game. The good things it has going for it are that the soundtrack is good, the hidden object gameplay is relaxing and satisfying, and the art is absolutely amazing. The art is very reminiscent of Amanita Design (e.g. Samarost, Machinarium).

One important thing to note about Tiny Bang Story that will make it or break it for you, though, is that the hidden object gameplay is periodically broken up by actual puzzles you have to solve or mini-arcade games where you have to navigate a pixel boat or airplane through some pixel trees and rocks, etc. These little puzzles and mini-games add more flavor and variety to the game, so on one hand they are welcome. On the other hand, the little atari-style mini games are not very fun, and they go on for what seems like an excessively long time, and if you make one mistake, you have to start the whole tedious thing over again. The puzzles are usually of the jigsaw or tangram variety, but there are some permutation or mathematical puzzles in there as well. At first these are very light and easy, but by the time you make it to the third or fourth area of the world, they suddenly become way more demanding and can be very cumbersome (I especially disliked the puzzle where you have to balance the luggage on the scales). This is especially true if you are primarily interested in the hidden object gameplay. You may find yourself wanting to just look up the solution so you can get back to searching for hidden objects and avoid being obstructed by these.

The game also has a hint system, which you can activate by swatting a bunch of flies until you fill up a hint meter, but in my experience, there were 2 or 3 situations where I pressed the hint button and it either did not give any hint at all (literally did nothing) or it gave me an absolutely useless hint, essentially telling me what my objective is or some other such information I already know.

Overall it seems like a pretty good game. I enjoyed the art and music, and I enjoyed how relaxing and warm it is. I personally felt the puzzles and mini-games got to be too cumbersome after a certain point, so I've lost my interest in finishing it, but it will be a very good game for the right kind of person.

reviewText:
Tiny Bang Story is primarily a hidden object game. The good things it has going for it are that the soundtrack is good, the hidden object gameplay is relaxing and satisfying, and the art is absolutely amazing. The art is very reminiscent of Amanita Design (e.g. Samarost, Machinarium).

One important thing to note about Tiny Bang Story that will make it or break it for you, though, is that the hidden object gameplay is periodically broken up by actual puzzles you have to solve or mini-arcade games where you have to navigate a pixel boat or airplane through some pixel trees and rocks, etc. These little puzzles and mini-games add more flavor and variety to the game, so on one hand they are welcome. On the other hand, the little atari-style mini games are not very fun, and they go on for what seems like an excessively long time, and if you make one mistake, you have to start the whole tedious thing over again. The puzzles are usually of the jigsaw or tangram variety, but there are some permutation or mathematical puzzles in there as well. At first these are very light and easy, but by the time you make it to the third or fourth area of the world, they suddenly become way more demanding and can be very cumbersome (I especially disliked the puzzle where you have to balance the luggage on the scales). This is especially true if you are primarily interested in the hidden object gameplay. You may find yourself wanting to just look up the solution so you can get back to searching for hidden objects and avoid being obstructed by these.

The game also has a hint system, which you can activate by swatting a bunch of flies until you fill up a hint meter, but in my experience, there were 2 or 3 situations where I pressed the hint button and it either did not give any hint at all (literally did nothing) or it gave me an absolutely useless hint, essentially telling me what my objective is or some other such information I already know.

Overall it seems like a pretty good game. I enjoyed the art and music, and I enjoyed how relaxing and warm it is. I personally felt the puzzles and mini-games got to be too cumbersome after a certain point, so I've lost my interest in finishing it, but it will be a very good game for the right kind of person.

reviewText:
The Tiny Bang Story is a neat but ultimately incomplete and disappointing game.

Pros:
-Great music and atmosphere

Cons:
-Gameplay has its moments but is generally mediocre and feels unrewarding
-No level select screen or way to return to previous levels
-No ending
-The game does not respect its own premise(see below)

The Tiny Bang Story starts off strong, with the music and art coming together to create a delightful fairy-tale atmoshere. Quickly though, the shiny aesthetic wears off to reveal a disappointing core game. The first level feels like it had by far the most effort put into it-perhaps to entice people with a nice demo?

The gameplay is roughly a 50/50 split between Where's Waldo-esque collection quests and simple logic puzzles. The logic puzzles range from decent to mediocre, with the mediocre ones lacking any way of achieving a solution other than brute force guessing or using a guide. One problem is that it is sometimes unclear what the player has achieved in the world by completing a puzzle. Several times I found myself looking around, trying to figure what had changed in the world as a result of finishing a puzzle. This greatly diminished the satisfaction of completing the puzzle.

The game's biggest flaw, though, lies in its lack of respect for its own premise. The game is divided into five levels, each containing 25 puzzle pieces that, ostensibly, you are supposed to collect in order to repiar the fractured world. On the third level, I neglected to collect several of the puzzle pieces before activating the end-of-level sequence. I was dismayed to discover that not only was there no way to return to the level to collect the rest of the pieces, but the game had progressed as if I had collected them all anyway. This was quite disappointing considering that collecting these pieces has been presented in the opening as the main goal of the game.

Due to this severe problem, combined with the lack of an ending and rampant use of the filler collection quests in a pretty short game, I cannot recommend The Tiny Bang Story. I think you can do a lot better in the adventure genre.

It's charming, quaint, and relaxing, but overall I can't recommend it.
For me, the worst aspect was the hint system. If you get stuck and need a hint (and you probably will), you have to stop what you're doing and click on these flies that buzz in from offscreen. It takes a good minute or two to fill up the hint meter, and when you need another hint you have to repeat the process. It would have been better if the meter gradually filled on its own, or if items collected gave you some meter. But if you try to use the hint and the object you need isn't visible on the screen (hidden behind a door), the hint won't activate. It's useful for not wasting hints on screens where there are no items, but I got stuck when the item I needed was behind a window that had to be opened by clicking on a tiny lever half the screen away. No hints for that, just frustrated spam-clicking.
After that, there's the puzzles. Most of them are super easy: some even tell you the answer in the hint. But lots of them rely on color recognition, a big no-no in game design. There are no options for color-blindness.
Finally, scattered throughout each chapter are puzzle pieces which are used to rebuild the world. But you don't actually need to collect all of the pieces to finish a level, or even the game. I was missing two pieces on the final level, and it just ended. Then I suddenly had all of them to finish the big puzzle. Then the game just ended. Just like that. There was no fanfare, no You did it!" The game just ended and you get to replay puzzles.
The game has its good points

The Tiny Bang story is a relaxing find-and-puzzle game, the graphical style, the music and the overal gameplay are very peaceful and cozy, although the game succeeds in frustrating the player in many of the unskippable minigames.
Gameplay:
The main gameplay element is finding items hidden within the scenary, items like lightbulbs, vents, puzzelpieces... Because these items are in most cases really well blended with the environment there is a help system, click enough mosquitoes  and they will show you where 1 hidden items is within the scene. This is a nice little help system because they force the player to look at the scene while trying to catch them, often finding the hidden item before actually using the clue. They also hold the player back from using hints all the time, because you need quite alot of them for one clue instead of filling over time like most help systems in game do.

Minigames:
There are quite alot of minigames within this game, 20 to be exact. Most of them are very relaxing and don't require any help, but there are a few ennoying ones where you really have to try and try to eventually solve them. These minigames never have any hints except for a paper with a drawing on it trying to explain what you have to do without using any text, and for most of them that is enough. But it would be nice to get a little bit of extra help on the difficult puzzels.

Story:
Although there is no player character and thus no real story, you do learn alot about the world and it's inhabitants through it's scenary.

Graphics:
As you can see in the screenshots of the game, the graphics consist of a very stylisch 2D side view of the world. The graphics are well done and are very fitting for the game and atmostphere.

Sound:
The background music is relaxing and suited the game well. Though the soundeffects of the mosquitoes did ennoy me after some while. There are no dialogues in the game, so I can't say anything about voice overs.

Conclusion:
Though it's a very short game to play through, it's definitely worth playing if you like more relaxing and calm puzzle games. It's a nice change of pace between all the other games, and a real candy for the eye. So I recommend it to anyone who can enjoy a more relaxing puzzle game.

Hidden object games have never been my thing, but after playing through this exquisite little gem, I may have to branch out a little. From the music to the charming little puzzles interspersed throughout, you'll find much more than a time waster on your hands.

With no conventional story to be had, the whole plot basically revolves around collecting the puzzle pieces that make up the world. You'll encounter an individual character in each area, and you'll see a broad narrative of a young boy's adventures as you go, but it's mainly background. Everything in this game is hidden in plain site, but a keen eye can spot the majority of the items often before you even need to pick them up. This is all bundled in an absolutely gorgeous art style that makes use of pastels to give an authentic painting look. Every puzzle has its own twist, and there was only one puzzle out of the dozens I encountered that seemed to not follow any discernable logic. Some of the puzzles you encounter are often more mini-games than anything, from a simon-says challenge to some challenges that look like they came straight from a Commodore 64. Variety isn't something I was expecting with this, but by god is there a lot.

The only hiccups in design is that once you leave an area, you can't return. Not that I found anyway. The early areas indicate the ending through obvious cues, but some of the last areas aren't as obvious, and it led to me leaving behind a few as yet unfound puzzle pieces (I think 3 in all). Curiously, I was still able to put the world back together without a single piece left out so it's not a big deal, but my OCD aches that I couldn't get the other pieces. That, and the hint system is nearly worthless, and kind of a pain in the butt to charge. You have to collect dozens of bugs for one use, and no matter if it's charged or not they still litter the screen. You won't need the hint system generally though, so it's all minor gripes, but a desire to turn off the bug hints was rather high for me.

There are few games that can put me at piece as easily as this one did, and it served as a wonderful sleepaid after work and the like. For something a little different that harkens back to the Pajama Sam days but with a sense of grace to it, it's really a genuinely pleasant experience, and that is hard to come by these days. Absolutely worth it.

I'm generally not the biggest fan of hidden object games, but if the hidden objects serve a sensible purpose, such as being part of an overall puzzle and leading to a variety of in-game puzzles, as they do in The Tiny Bang Story, I am wiling to spend a few hours playing through it.

The Tiny Bang Story has a pleasant and charming hand-drawn art style, hidden objects, and a range of mostly very casual puzzles, a few of which I found enjoyably tricky too. A puzzle game with no real challenges can easily get a bit too casual and thus boring.

Speaking of art style, I also enjoyed how some objects on the screen react to the mouse pointer, such as cables and lines shifting when you move over them. Quite nice. Though subtle, it makes the scene feel so much more alive.

There are in-game hints, with a clever and original time-delay between hints that seem to require a certain number of flies to be clicked on before a new one becomes available. Depending on what section you're in, a hint will either show you something you should be clicking on the screen, or it gives a solution hint to one of the puzzle games. It's simply nicely done.

The music is nice, downbeat and in the background, well suited for a game that requires focus such as this one, though it did start feeling a bit repetitive after a while - as music does in most games.

There is only one thing missing from this game, and that is decent video options to make it other than its original pixel dimensions. As I sometimes have to do this with older games anyway, it wasn't much bother for me just changing my screen's resolution through the control panel to suit the game.

In the end, I think it took me a bit less than 3.5 hour playing through the whole game, though with a few distractions along the way that probably kept me from doing it at optimum efficiency. At its current RRP, I think it is very decent value for money. On sale, or in a bundle, it should be mandatory shopping for anyone who loves puzzle games or even for those who just enjoy the art style.
